text: I do also very much appreciate how ever since I’ve been involved with the Julia community (almost 6 years now!), <@U681ELA87> has been tirelessly working on many of the parts that weren’t so interesting to many of the scientists / mathematicians (even though they often depended on such things as reading CSV files!).  He’s not only made them work, and handle many cases that cause other parsers to stumble, he’s managed to make them world class fast (which, to a performance geek like me, is especially fantastic!).

text: Sometimes I think it's crazy how much development is done by only a couple people. When people say a language has this or that great package, what it often means is just that there's this one dude who happens to have written it, it's not like it's "the language's" achievement

elements.text: Sometimes I think it's crazy how much development is done by only a couple people. When people say a language has this or that great package, what it often means is just that there's this one dude who happens to have written it, it's not like it's "the language's" achievement

text: On the other hand, at least in the Julia community, if you are that one person, and you need help about something, it’s easy to find people willing to go the extra mile, enabling you to build that great package, to everybody’s benefit.
